applicates

Procs

proc insertApply(call: NimNode): NimNode {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
turns a regular call node into an apply call   Source Edit 
proc pipeIntoCall(value, call: NimNode): NimNode {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
inserts value as first argument of call   Source Edit

Macros

macro `|`(appl: ApplicateArg; arg: untyped): untyped

attempted operator syntax for apply. if arg is in parentheses then its arguments are broken up, otherwise it is passed as a single argument

note that you can undefine operators you don't want via import except

Example:

import ../applicates
doAssert (x !=> x + 1) | 1 == 2
const foo = x !=> x + 1
doAssert foo | 1 == 2
doAssert ((a, b) !=> a + b) | (1, 2) == 3
  Source Edit 
macro `\`(call: untyped): untyped

converts a call expression to an applicate call expression

supports dot calls, if the given expression is not a dot expression or call or command then it will simply apply it with no arguments

Example:

const foo = x !=> x + 1
doAssert \foo(1) == 2
doAssert \1.foo == 2
const bar = (a, b) !=> a + b
doAssert \bar(1, 2) == 3
doAssert \1.bar(2) == 3
const baz = !=> 10
doAssert \baz() == 10
doAssert \baz == 10
  Source Edit 
macro `|>`(value, call): untyped

inserts value as first argument of call, and converts it to applicate call expression

if call is a dot call, it is not modified, so value becomes the second argument in the call

Example:

import ../applicates

const incr = fromSymbol(system.succ)
const multiply = fromSymbol(`*`)
const divide = fromSymbol(`/`)

let foo = 3 |>
  multiply(2) |>
  incr |>
  14.divide
doAssert foo == 2
  Source Edit 
macro chain(initial, calls): untyped
statement list chained version of |>

Example:

import ../applicates

const incr = fromSymbol(system.succ)
const multiply = fromSymbol(`*`)
const divide = fromSymbol(`/`)

let foo = chain 3:
  multiply 2
  incr
  14.divide
doAssert foo == 2
  Source Edit

Templates

template `!=>`(params, body): untyped
infix version of applicate, same parameter syntax

Example:

import ../applicates
doAssert (x !=> x + 1).apply(2) == 3
const foo = (a, b) !=> a + b
doAssert foo.apply(1, 2) == 3
  Source Edit 
template `!=>`(body): untyped
same as applicate(body)   Source Edit 
template `\=>`(params, body): untyped
alias for !=>

Example:

import ../applicates
doAssert (x \=> x + 1).apply(2) == 3
const foo = (a, b) \=> a + b
doAssert foo.apply(1, 2) == 3
  Source Edit 
template `\=>`(body): untyped
alias for !=>   Source Edit 
template `()`(appl: ApplicateArg; args: varargs[untyped]): untyped

Call operator alias for apply. Must turn on experimental Nim feature callOperator to use. Note that this experimental feature seems to be fairly broken. This definition might also go away if Nim starts to error on templates named to overload experimental operators (which it currently doesn't inconsistently with other routines), as a compiles check does not work with the experimental pragma in other modules.

It's hard to conditionally define routines based on experimental features. Nim currently does not error with experimental operator overloads if they are templates, so this specific routine works. However if you run into problems with the call operator, import except should do the trick.

  Source Edit 
template `|<`(arg: untyped; appl: ApplicateArg): untyped
flipped |   Source Edit
